title: Why are there bubbles in my aquarium water surface? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are, I think, maybe three possible reasons. One, if you have a Betta fish, the fish may have made a bubble nest, which is quite normal for these fish. It’ll eventually break up, but they’re kind of fun while they last. If you just did a water change, there may be tiny air bubbles coming up for some time, but it is temporary and quite harmless. But, if the water surface has a film on it, one that looks a bit like gasoline or oil on the water, or slightly cloudy, that’s a protein film. It’s very common, not particularly dangerous, and it can easily trap air bubbles at the surface so they don’t break and vanish as they usually would. The fix for protein films is to disturb the water surface enough to break it up, and once you do that, it’ll disappear. An air stone can work, or aim a small pump or filter upward so the water flow from it disturbs the surface just enough to get rid of the film.

I can’t see the surface of the water so I don’t know what bubbles you are seeing. But anytime items go in the aquarium there will be air that escapes. And when you add water, let it settle so “all” the air bubbles escape before you use it. But, then again, if you pour it quickly that there can be air bubbles as well. All should settle down. If there are bubbles on the glass, just run your hand over it and they’ll disappear.
